articles.snippet: Nine people were killed and 27 others were wounded, the police said. It was the second American mass shooting in 24 hours, and the third in a week.
articles.lead_paragraph: [For the latest updates, read our Monday live briefing on the Dayton and El Paso shootings.]
articles.abstract: Nine people were killed and 27 others were wounded, the police said. It was the second American mass shooting in 24 hours, and the third in a week.

headline.main: Gunman Kills 9 in Dayton Entertainment District

byline.original: By Timothy Williams and Farah Stockman

articles.snippet: Mass shootings in El Paso and Dayton, Ohio, took place less than 24 hours apart. We spoke to Times reporters in El Paso about the aftermath.
articles.lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher
articles.abstract: Mass shootings in El Paso and Dayton, Ohio, took place less than 24 hours apart. We spoke to Times reporters in El Paso about the aftermath.

headline.main: Two Days, Two Cities, Two Massacres

articles.snippet: Mass shootings in El Paso and Dayton, Ohio, took place less than 24 hours apart. We spoke to Times reporters in El Paso about the aftermath.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mass shootings in El Paso and Dayton, Ohio, took place less than 24 hours apart. We spoke to Times reporters in El Paso about the aftermath.
articles.abstract: Mass shootings in El Paso and Dayton, Ohio, took place less than 24 hours apart. We spoke to Times reporters in El Paso about the aftermath.

headline.main: Listen to ‘The Daily’: Two Days, Two Cities, Two Massacres

articles.snippet: Another 52 people were wounded by gunfire throughout Chicago from Friday evening to Sunday, as much of the nation’s attention was focused on shootings in Ohio and Texas.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — While much of the nation’s attention was focused on the gun massacres in El Paso and Dayton, Ohio, last weekend, Chicago was convulsed by its own burst of violence — the worst weekend the city has seen so far in 2019.
articles.abstract: Another 52 people were wounded by gunfire throughout Chicago from Friday evening to Sunday, as much of the nation’s attention was focused on shootings in Ohio and Texas.

headline.main: Chicago Has Its Worst Weekend of Gun Violence in 2019 as 7 Are Killed
headline.print_headline: 7 Killed in Chicago’s Worst Weekend of Violence in 2019

articles.snippet: The nine people who were killed outside a popular Dayton bar also included the mother of a newborn and a fitness and nutrition trainer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ned Peppers would not close for another hour, and the crowd inside the bar and on the outdoor patio early Sunday morning was lively. The line to get inside stretched around the block, and the revelers were black and white, men and women, spanning at least two generations. One was the mother of a newborn, another was a nutrition trainer. Within seconds, both would be dead, along with seven others.
articles.abstract: The nine people who were killed outside a popular Dayton bar also included the mother of a newborn and a fitness and nutrition trainer.

headline.main: Gunman’s Own Sister Was Among Dayton Shooting Victims
headline.print_headline: Among Nine Killed in Ohio, the Gunman’s Own ‘Bubbly’ Sister

byline.original: By Farah Stockman and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

articles.snippet: President Trump incorrectly named Toledo, Ohio, instead of Dayton, as the location of a mass shooting that occurred on Sunday.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump incorrectly named Toledo, Ohio, instead of Dayton, as the location of a mass shooting that occurred on Sunday.
articles.abstract: President Trump incorrectly named Toledo, Ohio, instead of Dayton, as the location of a mass shooting that occurred on Sunday.

headline.main: Trump Incorrectly References Toledo in Remarks on Mass Shootings

articles.snippet: There may be as many motivations as there are killers. But over the decades, scientists have seen some patterns emerge.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Monday morning, President Trump made his first televised statement about the mass murders committed over the weekend in El Paso, Tex., and Dayton, Ohio. He called for action to “stop mass killings before they start,” citing what he said were a number contributing factors: the contagious nature of mass murder; the glorification of violence in video games; and the need to act on “red flags” to identify and potentially confine the “mentally ill monsters” that he said commit the crimes.
articles.abstract: There may be as many motivations as there are killers. But over the decades, scientists have seen some patterns emerge.

headline.main: What Experts Know About People Who Commit Mass Shootings
headline.print_headline: What Drives People to Mass Shootings? Scientists Have Some Answers

articles.snippet: While the police investigated the shooting in Ohio that left nine dead, acquaintances of the gunman remembered his past threats toward women.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAYTON, Ohio — The police on Monday were still trying to determine what motivated a gunman in Dayton to kill his sister and eight others, but people who grew up with him were conducting a different kind of investigation, looking back for any signs that might have foreshadowed his explosion of violence.
articles.abstract: While the police investigated the shooting in Ohio that left nine dead, acquaintances of the gunman remembered his past threats toward women.

headline.main: Gunman in Dayton Had History of Threatening Women, Former Friends Say
headline.print_headline: In Dayton’s Aftermath, a Hunt for Clues to What Drove the Gunman

byline.original: By Campbell Robertson, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Timothy Williams

articles.snippet: In a country that has become nearly numb to men with guns opening fire in schools, at concerts and in churches, shooting in Texas and Ohio left the public shaken.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAYTON, Ohio — On Sunday, Americans woke up to news of a shooting rampage in an entertainment district in Dayton, Ohio, where a man wearing body armor shot and killed nine people, including his own sister. Hours earlier, a 21-year-old with a rifle entered a Walmart in El Paso and killed 20 people.
articles.abstract: In a country that has become nearly numb to men with guns opening fire in schools, at concerts and in churches, shooting in Texas and Ohio left the public shaken.

headline.main: Back-to-Back Outbreaks of Gun Violence in El Paso and Dayton Stun Country
headline.print_headline: One Shooting Massacre Follows Another, Shaking a Bewildered Nation to Its Core

byline.original: By Campbell Robertson, Julie Bosman and Mitch Smith

articles.snippet: The gun lobby has structural advantages and a Senate aligned with its stance. But activists have increased financing and grass-roots energy as they pursue their cause.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The political momentum in the gun control debate has shifted in the year leading up to this weekend’s mass shootings in El Paso and Dayton, Ohio, with gun control advocates taking a more empowered stance and the National Rifle Association consumed by internal power struggles.
articles.abstract: The gun lobby has structural advantages and a Senate aligned with its stance. But activists have increased financing and grass-roots energy as they pursue their cause.

headline.main: How Gun Control Groups Are Catching Up to the N.R.A.
headline.print_headline: Despite Recent Advances, Obstacles Persist for Gun Control Advocates

byline.original: By Reid J. Epstein, Maggie Astor and Danny Hakim

articles.snippet: This year, there have been at least 32 fatal shootings with three or more victims in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gun massacres killed 29 people over the weekend in El Paso and Dayton, Ohio, shaking the country and igniting a new debate over gun control.
articles.abstract: This year, there have been at least 32 fatal shootings with three or more victims in the United States.

headline.main: How Many Mass Shootings in 2019? Last Weekend Underscored the Violence

articles.snippet: This is what happens when our nation’s leader normalizes hate.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Like most Americans, I watched, devastated, as the news began to unfold Saturday morning. Another deadly mass shooting. This time in El Paso, and soon after Dayton, Ohio. In El Paso, 22 lives were taken; dozens more families and communities have been left to suffer in its wake.
articles.abstract: This is what happens when our nation’s leader normalizes hate.

headline.main: The El Paso Shooting Is the Violence Latinos Have Been Dreading

articles.snippet: President Trump addressed the country after mass shootings in El Paso and Dayton, Ohio, but he stopped short of endorsing broad gun control measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: Good Tuesday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.
articles.abstract: President Trump addressed the country after mass shootings in El Paso and Dayton, Ohio, but he stopped short of endorsing broad gun control measures.

headline.main: On Politics: A Nation in Mourning
headline.print_headline: Morning Edition

articles.snippet: Ohio’s governor proposed a bill that would make it easier for the police to seize guns from people deemed dangerous. Its prognosis is uncertain.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Two days after a gunman killed nine people outside a bar in Dayton, Gov. Mike DeWine of Ohio said Tuesday that he wanted to make it easier for the police to seize guns from people deemed dangerous.
articles.abstract: Ohio’s governor proposed a bill that would make it easier for the police to seize guns from people deemed dangerous. Its prognosis is uncertain.

headline.main: As Ohio and Texas Shootings Bring Calls for Change, Officials Try to ‘Thread the Needle’
headline.print_headline: Shootings Bring Call to ‘Do Something,’ but So Far Not Many States Have

byline.original: By Mitch Smith and David Montgomery

articles.snippet: In Texas and Ohio, it’s legal to buy these high-powered firearms, use them with large-capacity magazines and carry them in public with a permit.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Texas and Ohio, it’s legal to buy these high-powered firearms, use them with large-capacity magazines and carry them in public with a permit.
articles.abstract: In Texas and Ohio, it’s legal to buy these high-powered firearms, use them with large-capacity magazines and carry them in public with a permit.

headline.main: How State Laws Allowed Military-Style Guns Used in Dayton and El Paso Shootings

byline.original: By Larry Buchanan and K.K. Rebecca Lai

articles.snippet: The president took sharp aim at opponents even as he visited two cities in mourning after horrific mass shootings in Ohio and Texas.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump landed in El Paso on Wednesday afternoon to try to console a city reeling from tragedy, but was greeted by protesters after a contentious day in which he clashed with rivals and critics even as he visited with grieving residents in Dayton, Ohio.
articles.abstract: The president took sharp aim at opponents even as he visited two cities in mourning after horrific mass shootings in Ohio and Texas.

headline.main: Trump Visits Dayton and El Paso

articles.snippet: New restrictions passed the House only after Democrats won a majority. Activists don’t expect much from the G.O.P.-controlled Senate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By the time President Trump gave a speech about the weekend’s mass shootings in El Paso and Dayton, Ohio, on Monday, gun control advocates had long given up on his ability and desire to address gun violence in America.
articles.abstract: New restrictions passed the House only after Democrats won a majority. Activists don’t expect much from the G.O.P.-controlled Senate.

headline.main: Gun Control Groups, Having Given Up on Trump, Look to 2020

byline.original: By Reid J. Epstein and Maggie Astor

articles.snippet: How much responsibility does President Trump bear for violence motivated by racism? The columnists discuss gun control, the recent shootings in El Paso, Tex. and Dayton, Ohio and their connections to Trump’s dehumanizing statements about immigrant...
articles.lead_paragraph: How much responsibility does President Trump bear for violence motivated by racism? The columnists discuss gun control, the recent shootings in El Paso, Tex. and Dayton, Ohio and their connections to Trump’s dehumanizing statements about immigrants. Then, several 2020 Democrats took shots at Barack Obama’s legacy during last week’s presidential debates. Were they just trying to undermine Joe Biden’s appeal, or does the breakup with the most recent Democratic president signify something deeper?
articles.abstract: How much responsibility does President Trump bear for violence motivated by racism? The columnists discuss gun control, the recent shootings in El Paso, Tex. and Dayton, Ohio and their connections to Trump’s dehumanizing statements about immigrants. Then, several 2020 Democrats took shots at Barack Obama’s legacy during last week’s presidential debates. Were they just trying to undermine Joe Biden’s appeal, or does the breakup with the most recent Democratic president signify something deeper?

headline.main: Listen to ‘The Argument’: Does Trump Help Fuel Mass Shootings?

articles.snippet: After attacks in El Paso and Dayton killed more than 30 people, the astrophysicist apologized for his ill-timed attempt to add context.
articles.lead_paragraph: At least 31 people were killed in back-to-back mass shootings over the weekend — first in El Paso on Saturday, then in Dayton, Ohio, 13 hours later — leaving the country shaken and refueling the national conversation on access to firearms.
articles.abstract: After attacks in El Paso and Dayton killed more than 30 people, the astrophysicist apologized for his ill-timed attempt to add context.

headline.main: Neil deGrasse Tyson’s Tweet on Mass Shooting Deaths Strikes a Nerve
headline.print_headline: Neil deGrasse Tyson Embroiled Over Tweet

articles.snippet: Mr. Trump told reporters of the plans after a day of highly critical news coverage as he traveled to the sites of mass shootings in El Paso and Dayton, Ohio, that left 31 dead.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Wednesday night that he was “strongly considering” commuting the 14-year prison sentence of Rod R. Blagojevich, the former Illinois governor who was convicted of trying to essentially sell President Barack Obama’s vacated Senate seat for personal gain.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump told reporters of the plans after a day of highly critical news coverage as he traveled to the sites of mass shootings in El Paso and Dayton, Ohio, that left 31 dead.

headline.main: After Strongly Suggesting He May Commute Blagojevich’s Sentence, Trump Says Matter Is Under Review
headline.print_headline: Trump Tempers Support For Imprisoned Governor

articles.snippet: Covering the tragedies in Dayton and El Paso in an era of mass shootings.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Sunday morning, the country woke up to terrible news: back-to-back mass shootings in El Paso and Dayton.
articles.abstract: Covering the tragedies in Dayton and El Paso in an era of mass shootings.

headline.main: A Horrible Day, Horribly Familiar
headline.print_headline: A Horrible Day, Horribly Familiar

articles.snippet: As the president traveled to Dayton and El Paso after this weekend’s mass shootings, he was greeted by protesters and lashed out at rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL PASO — President Trump visited Dayton, Ohio, and El Paso on Wednesday on a day intended as a show of compassion to cities scarred by a weekend of violence, but which quickly devolved into an occasion for anger-fueled broadsides against Democrats and the news media.
articles.abstract: As the president traveled to Dayton and El Paso after this weekend’s mass shootings, he was greeted by protesters and lashed out at rivals.

headline.main: Trump Uses a Day of Healing to Deepen the Nation’s Divisions
headline.print_headline: President Uses  A Day of Healing  To Stoke Discord

byline.original: By Michael Crowley, Maggie Haberman, Mitch Smith and Michael D. Shear

articles.snippet: With Dayton, Ohio, and El Paso grieving after deadly mass shootings, visits from President Trump drew a sharp response from residents.
articles.lead_paragraph: With Dayton, Ohio, and El Paso grieving after deadly mass shootings, visits from President Trump drew a sharp response from residents.
articles.abstract: With Dayton, Ohio, and El Paso grieving after deadly mass shootings, visits from President Trump drew a sharp response from residents.

headline.main: Listen to ‘The Daily’: Two Cities in Mourning

articles.snippet: Mayor Nan Whaley has guided Dayton through repeated trauma this year. Before the recent mass shooting, the city was rocked by a Ku Klux Klan rally and tornadoes.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAYTON, Ohio — First, the Ku Klux Klan came to town. Two days later, tornadoes destroyed hundreds of homes and businesses and obliterated entire neighborhoods in and around the western Ohio city of Dayton.
articles.abstract: Mayor Nan Whaley has guided Dayton through repeated trauma this year. Before the recent mass shooting, the city was rocked by a Ku Klux Klan rally and tornadoes.

headline.main: ‘Something Just Keeps Happening’: Dayton Shooting Hit a City Already in Pain
headline.print_headline: Mayor in the Spotlight As Mass Shooting Rocks A City Already in Pain

byline.original: By Campbell Robertson and Mitch Smith

articles.snippet: Both cities are grieving after mass shootings last weekend, and opinions are divided over whether his arrival will provide comfort or incite rancor. The mood in El Paso is particularly fraught.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump will visit Dayton, Ohio, and El Paso on Wednesday in an attempt to deliver a message of national unity and healing to two cities scarred by mass shootings over the weekend and where many grieving residents hold him responsible for inflaming the country’s racial divisions.
articles.abstract: Both cities are grieving after mass shootings last weekend, and opinions are divided over whether his arrival will provide comfort or incite rancor. The mood in El Paso is particularly fraught.

headline.main: President Plans Visits to Places Where Grief Mixes With Anger at Him
headline.print_headline: President Plans Visits to Places Where Grief Mixes With Anger at Him

byline.original: By Michael Crowley, Rick Rojas and Campbell Robertson

articles.snippet: State laws that let judges take guns away from troubled owners have been used thousands of times, though they work only when people report threatening behavior.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year, a man who worked at a car dealership in San Diego told his co-workers that he would shoot up the place if he were fired, and he praised the man who had carried out the Las Vegas massacre.
articles.abstract: State laws that let judges take guns away from troubled owners have been used thousands of times, though they work only when people report threatening behavior.

headline.main: Red Flag Laws Can Save Lives. Shootings in El Paso and Dayton May Expand Them.
headline.print_headline: ‘Red Flag’ Laws Aren’t Airtight, but Officials Say They’ve Saved Lives

articles.snippet: The president became frustrated over his news coverage and his angry reaction led to White House-distributed media that focused on him, not people affected by the shootings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By the time President Trump arrived in El Paso on Wednesday, on the second leg of a trip to meet with people affected by mass shootings in two cities, he was frustrated that his attacks on his political adversaries had resulted in more coverage than the cheery reception he received at a hospital in Dayton, Ohio, the first stop on his trip. So he screamed at his aides to begin producing proof that in El Paso people were happy to see him.
articles.abstract: The president became frustrated over his news coverage and his angry reaction led to White House-distributed media that focused on him, not people affected by the shootings.

headline.main: Trump’s Trip to Dayton and El Paso: The Back Story
headline.print_headline: Thumbs Up and All Smiles, the President Strains to Send a Message

byline.original: By Katie Rogers, Maggie Haberman and Rick Rojas

articles.snippet: In the wake of the mass shootings in El Paso and Dayton, Democratic presidential candidates on Saturday emphasized the urgent need to confront gun violence in America.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — One by one, Democratic presidential candidates on Saturday emphasized the urgent need to confront gun violence in America, speaking largely in harmony on an issue that has been thrust to the forefront after last weekend’s mass shootings in El Paso and in Dayton, Ohio.
articles.abstract: In the wake of the mass shootings in El Paso and Dayton, Democratic presidential candidates on Saturday emphasized the urgent need to confront gun violence in America.

headline.main: Democrats in Iowa Offer Plans to Combat Gun Violence
headline.print_headline: In Combating Gun Violence, Democrats Present a United Front

articles.snippet: Universal Pictures said it pulled the movie, which is about people being hunted for sport, after two mass shootings left 31 dead.
articles.lead_paragraph: Universal Pictures on Saturday canceled plans to release “The Hunt” — a thriller about a group of “globalist elites” killing people for sport — after two recent mass shootings that left a total of 31 people dead in El Paso and in Dayton, Ohio.
articles.abstract: Universal Pictures said it pulled the movie, which is about people being hunted for sport, after two mass shootings left 31 dead.

headline.main: Movie Studio Cancels Release of ‘The Hunt’: ‘Now Is Not the Right Time’
headline.print_headline: Movie Studio Cancels Release of ‘The Hunt’ in Response to Shootings

articles.snippet: The police did not identify the gunman’s motive but said he had been obsessed with mass shootings.
articles.lead_paragraph: The gunman in last week’s massacre in Dayton, Ohio, texted his sister and another victim minutes before the shooting, the Dayton Police Department said in a news conference on Tuesday. The police also said the gunman was obsessed with mass shootings, but they declined to say what motivated the attack.
articles.abstract: The police did not identify the gunman’s motive but said he had been obsessed with mass shootings.

headline.main: Dayton Gunman Shot 26 People in 32 Seconds, Police Timeline Reveals
headline.print_headline: Ohio Gunman Was Obsessed With Violence And Shootings

articles.snippet: After shootings in Dayton and El Paso last month, the issue was already expected to top the agenda when lawmakers return from their recess next week. Now the pressure has intensified.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The deadly shooting spree in West Texas this weekend — the latest in an especially gruesome summer of massacres — has intensified pressure on congressional Republicans to take up gun safety legislation, giving fresh urgency to a debate that was already expected to be at the top of lawmakers’ agenda when they return to the Capitol next week.
articles.abstract: After shootings in Dayton and El Paso last month, the issue was already expected to top the agenda when lawmakers return from their recess next week. Now the pressure has intensified.

headline.main: Texas Shooting Brings New Urgency to Gun Debate in Congress
headline.print_headline: Texas Shooting Adds Urgency In Washington

articles.snippet: President Trump said officers and civilians who faced the mass shootings responded with “the best of American courage, character and strength.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It took just 20 seconds for police officers in Dayton, Ohio, to begin firing at a gunman one morning last month, taking him down after he  killed nine people and wounded 27 others in the city’s entertainment district.
articles.abstract: President Trump said officers and civilians who faced the mass shootings responded with “the best of American courage, character and strength.”

headline.main: Trump Honors Police Officers and Civilians in El Paso and Dayton Shootings
headline.print_headline: Trump Honors Police and Civilians in El Paso and Dayton Shootings
